Mr. Modi said the promise in the budget of doubling farmers’ income by 2022 was achievable with a good strategy, well-designed programmes, adequate resources and good governance in implementation. “In the past, the emphasis has been on agricultural output, rather than on farmers’ incomes.”

On the “spectacular” progress of the Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana, he said that over 31 million loans had been sanctioned to entrepreneurs for a total value of nearly $19 billion this year. Of these entrepreneurs, 77 per cent were women and 22 per cent were from the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

“Even if we assume conservatively that on average, each enterprise creates just one sustainable job, this initiative itself amounts to 31 million in new employment.”

He said the Stand-Up India scheme to be launched on April 5 would provide 2,50,000 entrepreneurship loans to women and Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

Mr. Modi defended his pet initiative, Make in India, and promised to remove all distortions in the tax structure disincentivising labour employment. “Corporate tax structure has favoured capital intensive production … created an artificial bias against labour.” He announced that it had been decided that the database of scores in the government and public sector undertakings recruitment examinations would be made available with candidate information open to all employers, wherever consent was given by the candidate.
title: ‘Govt plugging leakages in social expenditure, building infrastructure’
